channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Money Farmers: How Oligarchs and Populists Milk the E.U. for Millions
item.description: The European Union spends $65 billion a year subsidizing agriculture. But a chunk of that money emboldens strongmen, enriches politicians and finances corrupt dealing.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan, Matt Apuzzo and Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fields near Lovasbereny, Fejer County.

item.title: Hong Kong Protesters Call for U.S. Help. China Sees a Conspiracy.
item.description: The United States, viewed as a champion of democracy, occupies a symbolic role in the protests. Activists now want President Trump to take a tougher stand against Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters rallying last month in Hong Kong.

item.title: A Disgraced Ukrainian Oligarch’s Bizarre Ski Resort Plan
item.description: Plans to put a billion-dollar development in the middle of nowhere point to the revived fortunes of Ihor Kolomoisky, a patron of Ukraine’s new president.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: If a Ukrainian oligarch gets his way, Chorna Tysa, a village in the foothills of the Svydovets massif, could be tied to a billion-dollar ski resort.

item.title: Nigel Farage, Brexit Party Leader, Says He Won’t Run in Election
item.description: Mr. Farage said he planned instead to campaign aggressively against Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Brexit agreement.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Jeff Overs/BBC, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, right, the Brexit Party leader, on the BBC program “The Andrew Marr Show” that was broadcast on Sunday.

item.title: She Was Daddy’s Little Girl. At 3, She Watched Him Shot Dead.
item.description: The assassination of an Afghan government employee while his daughter was next to him has underscored the lasting trauma of the intensifying war.
item.dc:creator: Taimoor Shah and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan man paying his respects after the funeral for four people killed by a strike in Bati Kot District, Nangarhar Province, last year.

item.title: Nigerian Women Say ‘MeToo.’ Critics Say ‘Prove It.’
item.description: Women in West Africa who accuse men of sexual abuse have recently seen some change, but also an intense backlash — including threats and even a police investigation.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: KC Nwakalor for The New York Times
item.media:description: After accusing her former pastor of rape, Busola Dakolo received a visit from Nigerian police, who told her she was being investigated in a case of criminal conspiracy.

item.title: In the Amazon, Fires Steal Breath, but Smoke Smells of Money
item.description: The thousands of fires set to clear land for cattle in Brazil’s rainforest are widely seen as an environmental disaster. Local ranch hands have more conflicted feelings.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Amazon canopy smoldering near a cattle ranch in Mato Grosso state at the end of August.

item.title: U.K. Halts Fracking in England, Citing Quake Concerns
item.description: Boris Johnson’s government, which is preparing for a general election, said the ban would be in place until there was “compelling new evidence” that it could be carried out safely.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters marching outside the Preston Prison in England last year, in support of three activists who were jailed for blocking a fracking site.

item.title: What Could Come Between These Two Allies? A $100 Jar of Honey
item.description: New Zealand producers, in the face of protests by their Australian counterparts, want to trademark manuka honey, a costly nectar beloved by celebrities.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Checking hives that produce manuka honey near Hamilton, New Zealand, on Monday.

item.title: He Left His 310-Year-Old Violin on a Train. He Retrieved It in a Parking Lot.
item.description: The musician Stephen Morris said, “I’m still getting over the shock” at the unlikely recovery of his instrument.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra

item.title: Mali Says 54 Are Killed in Jihadist Attack on Army; ISIS Claims Responsibility
item.description: At least 53 soldiers and one civilian died in one of the deadliest attacks to hit the nation’s military in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Malian soldiers on parade in Bamako last year. At least 53 soldiers and one civilian have been killed in a jihadist attack which was one of the deadliest strikes against the West African country’s military in recent memory.

item.title: Hong Kong Protests: Police Face Off With Demonstrators After Election Rally
item.description: The event, which was billed as a campaign event for local elections, quickly descended into chaos around the city.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Under Trump, Iraqis Who Helped U.S. in War Are Stalled in Refugee System
item.description: Just 4,000 have been deemed eligible to enter the United States over the next year, and a slowdown in the screening process means far fewer are likely to come.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A camp for displaced people south of Mosul, Iraq, in 2017. As of today, an estimated 110,000 Iraqis are waiting to be approved as refugees based on their wartime assistance.

item.title: ‘Chile Woke Up’: Dictatorship’s Legacy of Inequality Triggers Mass Protests
item.description: The promise was that free markets would lead to prosperity, and prosperity would take care of other problems. It did not really work out that way.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A barricade at the center of a street following a protest last week.

item.title: Flood of Oil Is Coming, Complicating Efforts to Fight Global Warming
item.description: New supplies from Brazil, Canada, Guyana and Norway may add to a glut, posing a threat to producers in Saudi Arabia, Russia and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: A Norwegian oil platform in the North Sea. Norway’s production has declined for two decades, but its development of the Johan Sverdrup deepwater field should reverse the trend.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Saudi Aramco, President Trump, WeWork.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Melina Delkic

item.title: Why Barbie, a Blimp and a Wienermobile Are Posting on Airbnb
item.description: The home-sharing platform has offered several novelty lodging opportunities lately, like a stay in Barbie’s mansion or a night in the Goodyear blimp. They earn headlines, and that’s the point.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The Barbie Dreamhouse in Malibu, Calif., didn’t really exist as such until Mattel teamed up with Airbnb to turn the mansion into a marketing opportunity.

item.title: Walter Mercado, Celebrity Astrologer, Is Dead
item.description: For years, he kept Latino families glued to their televisions as he dramatically revealed their futures, as foretold by the stars.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Alberto E. Tamargo/Sipa USA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mr. Mercado at an exhibition in August at the HistoryMiami Museum that celebrated his career.

item.title: Final Exhibition by Okwui Enwezor Will Open in 2021 in Middle East
item.description: The Sharjah Biennial will present a posthumous show by the acclaimed Nigerian curator, who died this year at the age of 55.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:description: Okwui Enwezor, in 2015. His final show will soon be realized, as the 15th edition of the Sharjah Biennial.

item.title: We Just Wanted to Talk E.U. Farm Policy. Why Was Someone Always Looking Over Our Shoulders?
item.description: The European Union conceals data showing where billions in subsidies go. So we needed a workaround.
item.dc:creator: Matt Apuzzo
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fields in Fejer County, Hungary.

item.title: Corrections: November 3, 2019
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, November 3, 2019.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump’s Plan to Bar Immigrants Who Can’t Pay for Health Care
item.description: The court ruling is the latest to derail administration initiatives to limit the admission of certain legal immigrants into the United States.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: President Trump’s proclamation barred immigrants who could not prove they had health insurance or the ability to pay for medical costs once they became permanent residents of the United States.

item.title: Explosion in Syrian Town on Turkish Border Kills 13
item.description: At least 13 people were killed and more than 30 injured in the Syrian town of Tal Abyad after a car bomb exploded in a market on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion that killed 13 and injured 30 people on the Syrian border town of Tal Abyad.

item.title: Boris Johnson Has Big Lead in U.K. Election. That Might Not Mean Much.
item.description: In Britain’s Brexit-scrambled politics, four parties are competing and the winning margins will be narrow. Nothing in this campaign is likely to go as the experts predict.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris J Ratcliffe
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson looking at old photographs of London with students at Abbots Green Primary Academy in Bury St Edmunds, Britain.

item.title: Corrections: November 2, 2019
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, November 2, 2019.

item.title: Iraq Demonstrations Grow, and Government Scrambles to Respond
item.description: Shiite authorities and Iraq’s president offered support for peaceful protesters, a move that emboldened more Iraqis to join antigovernment demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: The demonstration in Baghdad on Friday was the largest in a month’s worth of protests.

item.title: Azam Taleghani, Defiant Would-Be President of Iran, Dies at 76
item.description: A dissident politician and women’s rights advocate, she sought repeatedly to be accepted as a presidential candidate but each time was denied.
item.dc:creator: Arash Azizi
item.media:description: Azam Taleqani after registering as a presidential candidate in Tehran in 2005. Though barred from running, she did not give up her quest.

item.title: Last Major Nuclear Arms Pact Could Expire With No Replacement, Russia Says
item.description: The treaty, disliked by President Trump, will run out in 14 months — and there is too little time to hammer out a new one, a Russian official said.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña, Ivan Nechepurenko and David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump and Russian Vladimir Putin at the G20 summit in Osaka this year. The main nuclear weapons control pact between the United States and Russia is set to expire.

item.title: White House Freezes Military Aid to Lebanon, Against Wishes of Congress, State Dept. and Pentagon
item.description: The indefinite hold halts a $105 million package that the State Department and Congress had approved. Analysts say the winners could be Iran, Russia, the Islamic State and Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Vivian Yee and Michael Crowley
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Lebanese army soldiers facing anti-government protesters last week in Beirut.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in November
item.description: Our picks for November, including The Queen, Queer Eye and Catastrophe
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: Threats and Abuse Prompt Female Lawmakers to Leave U.K. Parliament
item.description: Eighteen female members of Parliament are not seeking re-election. Many say a barrage of abuse, online and offline, factored into their decision.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: “Nobody in any job should have to put up with threats,” a female member of Parliament said.

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.description: Pete Wells on Peter Luger. Elizabeth Warren’s “Medicare for all” plan. Greta Gerwig’s “Little Women.” Thom Yorke. And more.
item.dc:creator: Kaly Soto
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry

item.title: Pakistani Train Inferno Was Decades in the Making
item.description: The nation’s railway system has long been plagued by corruption and mismanagement, despite serving as the only link between many cities and towns.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of the burnt carriages a day after one of the deadliest train accidents in Pakistan’s history.

item.title: The Reawakening of Quebec’s Nationalism
item.description: The surge of the Bloc Québécois reflects the extent to which Quebecers recoil when the rest of Canada tries to tell them what to do.
item.media:description: The Bloc Québécois leader, Yves-François Blanchet, reacted after the Oct. 21 federal election.

item.title: U.K. Truck Deaths Lead Vietnam Police to Arrest 2 Suspects
item.description: The arrests, linked to the discovery of 39 bodies in England, came as the British authorities urged two men to turn themselves in to the police in Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police in Vietnam arrested two people as part of the investigation into the 39 bodies found in a truck in England in October.

item.title: 39 Vietnamese Died in a U.K. Truck. 18,000 More Endure This Perilous Trip.
item.description: Thousands of people from Vietnam are smuggled to Europe every year on a route filled with violence and hardship. And that is just the beginning.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks at the port in Holyhead, Wales, in October. Thirty-nine people, many of them believed to be Vietnamese, were found dead in a truck container in southeastern England.

item.title: Uber Driver in Lebanon Is Sentenced to Death in Killing of U.K. Diplomat
item.description: Rebecca Dykes, who was last seen leaving a bar in Beirut, was found strangled with a rope in 2017.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: A family photo of Rebecca Dykes, an employee at the British Embassy in Beirut who was killed in 2017.

item.title: New Delhi, Choking on Toxic Air, Declares Health Emergency
item.description: Schools were closed after pollution in India’s capital soared, reaching levels many times the global safe limit.
item.dc:creator: Kai Schultz and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: New Delhi on Friday. Officials declared a health emergency in response to dangerous air quality this week.

item.title: China Effectively Bans Online Sales of E-Cigarettes
item.description: The move could effectively shut off one of the biggest markets for an industry that is facing pressure around the world.
item.dc:creator: Elsie Chen and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Boxes of e-cigarettes on a production line at First Union, one of China’s leading manufacturers of vaping products.

item.title: Turkey Hands Over 18 Captured Syrian Soldiers
item.description: The announcement came as Russian and Turkish forces began their first joint patrol along the Syrian border.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Turkish and Russian military vehicles on a joint patrol along the Turkish border town of Kiziltepe on Friday.

item.title: 2 Cabinet Ministers Resigned in Japan. Their Downfall? Melons and Potatoes.
item.description: The undoing of top officials showed the country’s low tolerance for anything with even a hint of political bribery.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Japan's trade minister, Isshu Sugawara, resigned after being accused of giving melons and crab to voters.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in November
item.description: New additions include “The King,” staring Timothée Chalamet, Martin Scorsese’s “The Irishman” and “The Crown: Season 3”
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Macron Steps Into a Leadership Vacuum in Europe, and on Some Toes
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron wants to lead, but his lone-wolf act has annoyed European colleagues, undermining his efforts.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France welcoming Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany to discuss European matters earlier this month.

item.title: Fighting Social Injustice Through Graffiti, and Making a Business of It
item.description: Camilo Fidel López’s leftist parents groomed him to save the world through the law. Instead, the 38-year-old Colombian is trying to do it with street art.
item.dc:creator: Perry Garfinkel
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of a Colombian girl with coffee beans, painted by Vértigo Graffiti, towers over the Kadikoy neighborhood of Istanbul.

item.title: Impeachment, Elizabeth Warren, ISIS: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Turkey Wants Refugees to Move to a ‘Safe Zone.’ It’s a Tough Sell.
item.description: With forces from the Assad regime deploying in their old lands, Syrians are afraid to go back home.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ammar, a Syrian refugee, harvesting parsley alongside Turkish women and children in the border village of Kavalcik.

item.title: Professors, Beware. In China, Student Spies Might Be Watching.
item.description: In a throwback to the Mao era, China is deploying students as watchdogs against teachers. It’s part of a campaign by President Xi to eliminate dissent.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: You Shengdong, a professor, was fired by a university in China last year after students reported him for questioning a political slogan favored by Xi Jinping, the country’s leader.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: ISIS, Brexit, Greta Gerwig
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Beer With Bella: Benjamin Law
item.description: The author and essayist shares insights on immigrant striving, social media and Australia’s imperfect meritocracy.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Toronto’s City of Tomorrow Is Scaled Back Amid Privacy Concerns
item.description: The overhaul envisioned by a sibling company of Google has been lauded for its innovations. It’s also been called a “corporate surveillance state.”
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Plans to overhaul Toronto’s eastern waterfront have envisioned automatic awnings, sidewalks that melt snow and sensors that track people’s movements.

item.title: Speaker John Bercow Bows Out, Loved and Loathed. Much Like Brexit.
item.description: Let the ‘chuntering’ begin: The sheriff of Britain’s Parliament has laid down his badge. But maybe not his thesaurus.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Speaker John Bercow has resigned after a decade in his position in Parliament.

item.title: ‘A Very Dangerous Game’: In Latin America, Embattled Leaders Lean on Generals
item.description: Presidents are increasingly asking militaries to bail them out of crises, surfacing painful memories in a region where many grew up under military rule.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher

item.title: Jennifer Davis, 85, Dies; Led Divestment Effort Over Apartheid
item.description: After leaving South Africa, she pressed colleges, churches, unions, philanthropies and others to unload their stock in companies profiting from a racist system.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Jennifer Davis, right, at a demonstration outside the South African Embassy in Washington in 1987. She worked to promote disinvestment from South Africa as a tool in the struggle against apartheid.

item.title: Iran’s Leaders See Threats in Iraq and Lebanon Protests
item.description: Enormous antigovernment demonstrations in Iraq and Lebanon, some tinged with hostility toward Iran, have suddenly put Iran’s interests at risk.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Iraqi protesters near the high-security Green Zone in Baghdad on Tuesday. The protesters are worrying to neighboring Iran.

item.title: Bolivia’s Democracy Faces Pivotal Test as Unrest Spreads
item.description: Allegations that the governing party rigged the Oct. 20 election have sparked violent protests and calls for a new election.
item.dc:creator: Mónica Machicao and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Protesters disputing the results of the Oct. 20 election in Bolivia.

item.title: Trump Wades Into U.K. Election, and Farage Might Benefit
item.description: He heaped praise on Prime Minister Boris Johnson during a London radio show, but his biggest gift might have been to Nigel Farage, whose party is casting for ways to influence the Dec. 12 vote.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Boris Johnson at the United Nations in September.

item.title: Hong Kong, Kashmir, Impeachment Inquiry: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Hong Kong falls into recession.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Andrea Kannapell

item.title: Outrage Greets Verdict in Sex Attack on Unconscious Teenager
item.description: A Spanish court sentenced five men on charges of sexual abuse, not rape, in the assault of a 14-year-old. The ruling was likely to intensify debate over whether the judiciary treats sexual assault fairly.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder

item.title: France Strips 7 Police Officers of Guns After Paris Attack
item.description: A fatal attack by an employee at headquarters in Paris has prompted increased internal vigilance, but experts warned about religious stereotyping.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Officers stood guard at Paris Police Headquarters on Oct. 3, the day a police employee fatally stabbed four colleagues.

item.title: Measles Makes Your Immune System’s Memory Forget Defenses Against Other Illnesses
item.description: New research shows the virus can have devastating effects on the immune system that persist much longer than the illness itself.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: A measles patient and her mother in a hospital in the Philippines, in May. Globally, most of the 100,000 people who die each year from measles are children aged 5 years or younger.

item.title: Spain Agrees to Host Key Climate Talks After Chile Pulls Out
item.description: Madrid has offered to hold the next United Nations climate talks, the leaders of Spain and Chile announced on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Pedro Sánchez, Spain’s prime minister, speaking at a campaign event on Monday.
